Award.AwardTitle: Material Removal Mechanisms in Vortex Machining

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to obtain an understanding of a new, nanometer level, surface removal process that utilizes locally induced vortices of polishing slurry. These vortices are produced by a micrometer scale oscillating fiber immersed in the fluid near to the surface to be machined, the vortices being stationary relative to the probe. Probes of varied diameters (7 µm to 400 µm), oscillating at high frequencies (over 100 Hz to 10?s of kHz) will produce localized vortices of varying size and magnitude resulting in material removal footprints with lateral dimensions of less than a millimeter. The size of the process footprint will be controlled by the amplitude and frequency of the driving oscillations and the orientation of the probe with respect to the workpiece. An analytical model will be used to isolate the fiber sizes and drive frequencies required to produce differing vortex patterns and velocity profiles. An in-house experimental set-up will enable correlations between the predicted vortex dynamics and the actual process material removal footprints. Actual mechanisms (process parameters and slurry composition) contributing to material removal rates and surface quality will also be investigated.

If successful this project will realize a relatively low cost technology with the following features and capabilities; 1) sub millimeter sized tooling of controllable size, 3) the ability to remove material from highly localized regions without imparting damage into the workpiece, 4) the ability to finish traditionally challenging geometries such as micro fluidic channels and re-entrant features, and 5) the ability to remove mid spatial frequency errors imparted by current subaperture processes that use larger tooling. This will be accompanied by experimental verification of analytical models which will facilitate expedient isolation of optimal process parameters. The undergraduate and graduate students involved will gain competency in core technologies relevant to US manufacturing such as micro-manufacturing, precision design, metrology, and chemistry Demonstration modules will be developed to promote science and engineering subjects through summer camp programs and to highlight the interdisciplinary nature of precision engineering in graduate level Mechanical Engineering, Optics and Nanoscale Science programs.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Broader impacts and intellectual merits of this project

This project has demonstrated a technique for polishing small regions on a surface with molecular level smoothness for which polishing on silica, silicon and steel has been demonstrated. It was determined by this project that the mechanism of removal is not the same as originally thought, it is a micro-polishing mechanism. This work details the pre-requisites for this micromachining to be possible. Machine design is pivotal if this process is to find industrial application for which the parameters for machine performance are now known. It is still the only machining process with this capability.

What it is

Vortex machining is a highly localized polishing method, achieved by immersing the specimen in a slurry of abrasive powders mixed in a liquid of controlled chemical properties. In our studies, a fine carbon fiber, having a diameter of 7 micrometers (about 1/10th of the diameter of a human hair) and around 3.5 mm long is placed in the slurry and positioned so that its tip is in close proximity to the specimen surface. This fiber, being attached to a quartz oscillator, is then vibrated at 32,000 Hertz for periods of 5 to 30 minutes. An artistic rendering of this is shown in Figure 1. With this micro-scale fiber, it has been demonstrated that polished spots can be as small as 10 micrometers across and a few tens of nanometers deep.  To increase the size of the polished region we also produced a high-power machine capable of oscillating larger rods of up to 0.5 mm in diameter.

Machine development

At the outset of the project, a first generation machine developed as part of a project funded by the Center for Precision Metrology at UNC Charlotte was used. However initial machining studies revealed that a new machine would require a substantial improvement in positioning control and stability (from 10 to 1 micrometer).  Further studies showed that slurry evaporation also affected the repeatability of the process. After substantial and necessary development, a new low-power machining facility was capable of providing stable position of the machining probe relative to the specimen as well as the height of the slurry to sub-micrometer precision, Figure 2. Similar issues also resulted in the design evolution of the higher power system. Building both systems represented substantial development over the first two years of this project.

Machining, measurement, and analysis

Following machining, it was necessary to analyze the resulting footprints left by the process. Requiring nanometer precision and resolution, measurements of the footprints were obtained using scanning white light interferometry (SWLI) and atomic force microscopy (AFM). To extract relevant information from this data a suite of software programs were developed to compute the volume of material removed and the surface roughness within the footprints. Figure 3 (left) shows individual footprints, and (right) an array of twelve footprints achieved using the automated machining capabilities of the low-power system.

Systematic experimentation

The extensive machine developments were driven by observations of instabilities of the machining process. Consequently, it was necessary to undertake numerous systematic studies to evaluate factors that were considered to influence, often adversely, the machining process. Major studies undertaken include;

  • Probe manufacture and subsequent amplitude and stability of the oscillation of the fiber.
  • The effect of the slurry depth on oscillation amplitudes with reference also to position of the meniscus interface relative to the nodes of the resonating fiber.
  • Wear of the fiber due to the machining process and cleaning of the probes.
  • The effect of the slurry composition on different materials.
